data.Title: Reddit Restricts Search Engine Access to Recent Content, Google Excluded
data.Description: Reddit is blocking AI bots from major search engines unless they strike a deal.  As a result, Google is now the only search engine that shows recent Reddit posts in results. This has sparked debate on data access and AI training practices, with some arguing that the open web is being walled off.

data.Title: Microsoft Bing Introduces AI-Powered Generative Search
data.Description: Microsoft Bing Adds AI to Search Results, Following Google’s Lead. Bing search results organized by AI, now in limited release, will feature prominent links to external sites. The new feature highlights AI-generated answers, placing them front and center, while traditional search results take a backseat.

data.Title: OpenAI Launches SearchGPT, Competing with Google in Search
data.Description: OpenAI enters Google-dominated search engine market with SearchGPT. The move, announced on Thursday, also places the AI giant in competition with its largest backer Microsoft's Bing search. Search as we know it is officially over.

data.Title: Google Advises Against Using LLMs for SEO Advice
data.Description: Google's John Mueller said on LinkedIn he does not recommend you use LLMs (AI tools) for SEO advice.  He wrote, "please don't use LLMs for SEO advice."  "They learn from all the bad SEO information out there," he added.

data.Title: Google Tests New Features in Search Results and Discover
data.Description: Google is experimenting with several new features in its search results, including a related images carousel, a "call business" option for local businesses, and AI Overviews with buttons to jump to Search. The company is also reportedly showing X/Twitter carousels less often for news queries.

data.Title: Google Merchant Center Feed Update Impacts Ecommerce Websites
data.Description: Ecommerce websites are experiencing a surge in pages being tracked by SEO platforms, potentially due to a Google Merchant Center feed update. It remains unclear whether this is a bug or a planned change.

data.Title: Google's Evolving Stance on Third-Party Cookies and International Targeting
data.Description: Google is not going to deprecate third-party cookies in Chrome. However, the company suggests ccTLDs could lose SEO value in years' time due to creative branding use, urging focus on content and hreflang for international targeting.
